text: The bill will address the shortage by investing $52 billion through the Creating Helpful Incentives to Produce Semiconductors (CHIPS) for America Act & by creating a Supply Chain Resiliency Program to prevent future shortages of essential materials & goods like semiconductors.

Last month, Sen. @Ossoff and @SenatorWarnock urged expedited passage of the bill to help boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing after @Kia's plant in West Point, GA, closed for two days as a result of worldwide semiconductor shortages.
https://www.ajc.com/ajcjobs/chip-shortage-forces-kias-west-point-ga-plant-to-shut-for-two-days/QXU2AL5PIZFBJPWRG3SWGSCERU/

“Georgians sent us here to fight for jobs & opportunity, and that’s why @SenatorWarnock & I united to help push this vital bill over the line and boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing — because Georgia jobs were on the line." -Sen. @ossoff

BREAKING: Following a strong push by Sen. @Ossoff and @SenatorWarnock to expedite passage of the bill, the U.S. Senate just passed the bipartisan U.S. Innovation & Competition Act, which includes $52 billion to boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing.

https://www.ossoff.senate.gov/press-releases/following-ossoff-warnock-push-u-s-senate-passes-bipartisan-legislation-to-boost-domestic-semiconductor-production/

My mom would be so excited by the progress we’ve made in the last decade, but I know she’d be telling me to “keep on it,” -- to keep pushing forward the mission for equality.

She passed away in 2011, so she never got to see marriage equality become a reality. I’ll never forget watching her longtime partner, Annie, care for her, knowing our state didn’t recognize their commitment to each other under the law.

If we’d waited for bipartisanship, there wouldn’t be a 14th or 15th Amendment. We wouldn't have some of our most important civil rights laws.

Let's learn, do what’s right, and pass the For the People Act. If you wait for bipartisanship, you're allowing voter suppression.

EVERY SINGLE ONE of these landmark bills was passed WITHOUT bipartisan votes even though these bills — like civil rights legislation including the For the People Act today — were supported by a majority of voters.

They were: 
✅The 1866 Civil Rights Bill
✅The 14th Amendment
✅The 15th Amendment
✅The 1870 Enforcement Act
✅The Klu Klux Klan Act
✅The 1872 Enforcement Act
✅The 1875 Civil Rights Bill
✅The 1875 Enforcement Act
✅The Lodge Bill

Between 1866 and 1890, there were NINE landmark civil rights laws enacted by Congress.

None of them received bipartisan votes but all of them were popular, urgent, and necessary for taking critical steps towards equality, justice, and opportunity for Black people across America.

Gasp! Who would’ve thought??

Today Senate Republicans blocked the #PaycheckFairness Act and voted against equal pay for all women. This commonsense, long-overdue solution would help women, their families, and our economy as a whole—and while it didn't pass today, our work is far from over.

RT @SenAlexPadilla Equal pay is a racial justice issue.
 
Black women, AAPI women, Latina women, and Indigenous women deserve equal pay for equal work.

There is absolutely nothing controversial about making sure every worker gets paid fairly for their work—women have been waiting long enough and they need the #PaycheckFairness Act now more than ever.

Let’s get this done.

The #PaycheckFairness Act is very straightforward—it closes loopholes that allow pay discrimination to continue, protects workers from retaliation, limits the use of prior wage history in the hiring process, and increases transparency and accountability.

Right now, women in the U.S. still on average earn only 82 cents on the dollar compared to their male counterparts—and the wage gap is far greater for women of color.

It’s unacceptable and wrong—and the current economic and jobs crisis has only made things worse.

RT @rosadelauro The Senate vote on the #PaycheckFairness Act should not have been a partisan vote but rather a vote of conscience. Congress passed the Equal Pay Act nearly 60 years ago, and still, women are paid less on average than their male counterparts—the gap is highest for women of color.
The House and Senate must immediately begin working on budget resolutions to pass the American Jobs and Families Plan through reconciliation so we can deliver on our promises.

President Biden has laid out a big, bold vision, and it is urgent. We’ve got people of all political ideologies with us.

The next step is clear: let’s do what the people are demanding.

Every day wasted trying to get Republicans on board is another day that people can’t go back to work because they don’t have child care.

Another day without investing in millions of good, union jobs.

Another day that we lose further ground on the climate crisis.

These are the same Republican Senators who: 

➖Voted against the American Rescue Plan, even if some touted its benefits after voting no

➖ Refused to pass a bipartisan commission to investigate the January 6 insurrection

➖Refused to vote for pay equity

It would be foolish to think Republican Senators will suddenly go against Leader McConnell’s goal of blocking President Biden’s agenda, and support investments in affordable housing, health care, or paid leave — even though they are widely popular across the political spectrum.
In case it wasn’t clear already, it certainly is now: Republicans are not going to do what needs to be done for working families.

A reformed charitable deduction would be a means of making our tax code fairer, a precautionary defense against one obstacle to civil society, and a step towards a renewal of America’s voluntary institutions.

Those who argue that but for government overreach, civil society would be flourishing, should be asking exactly which government policies need correction, and the charitable deduction should be high on the list.

H.R. 1446 provides the background check system with additional time to make a final determination on a potential firearms purchaser before a licensed dealer can transfer a gun, addressing the so-called “Charleston loophole.”

Let us work together to bring about meaningful gun safety reform legislation, including H.R. 8 and H.R. 1446, which enhances background checks. 

H.R. 8 makes it unlawful to sell or transfer a firearm in ANY transaction without a Brady Background Check.

The 'Firearm Safety Act' would bring guns and ammunition under the jurisdiction of the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC). This common-sense reform would allow the CPSC to issue safety standards for guns and ammunition that will help reduce gun-related deaths.

The 'Keeping Guns from High-Risk Individuals Act' was reintroduced in February and would prohibit the sale or transfer of guns to individuals who have been convicted of certain aggressive and high-risk behaviors.

The 'Recognizing Gun Violence as a Public Health Emergency Act' was reintroduced in February, requiring the U.S. Surgeon General to submit an annual report to Congress on the public health impacts of gun violence.

The month of June is National Gun Violence Awareness Month. It is not a month for 'moments of silence.' It is not a month for 'condolences.'

It is a month in which to take action to end #gunviolence with gun safety reform legislation.
